quotes.topic_title: Everyday persuasion using contrast frameworks
quotes.text: A lot of people think that the only time you really need to present well is when you have a big stage talk and you make the big investment in the script.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that presentation skill only matters for high-stakes, formal talks.

quotes.topic_title: Everyday persuasion using contrast frameworks
quotes.text: I can get my husband to do chores for me on the weekends with a real quick, what is, what could be new bliss.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how the “what is vs what could be” contrast can drive everyday persuasion.

quotes.topic_title: Everyday persuasion using contrast frameworks
quotes.text: So, the ability to just have that contrast as a framework in your brain during a meeting, on a phone call, any moment of influence, like literally it works.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to apply the contrast framework in real-time across common work situations.

quotes.topic_title: Everyday persuasion using contrast frameworks
quotes.text: It works in any format.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A memorable, portable takeaway that reinforces the universality of the contrast method.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Nancy is a bestselling author, speaker, and CEO of Duarte Incorporated, which has helped create over 250,000 presentations for the world's most influential business leaders, brands and institutions including Apple, TED, Google, the World Bank, and famously Al Gore on his Inconvenient Truth presentation.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete credibility/data point showing the scale and caliber of Duarte’s presentation work, useful as a benchmark for what “world-class” looks like.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Nancy shares a ton of tactical advice for how to improve your own presentations, how to tell better stories, how to lay out convincing arguments, how to reduce your nerves when you present, and even a simple communication framework to improve your relationship dynamics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise checklist of practical skill areas the episode will cover—presentations, storytelling, argument structure, nerves, and a relationship communication framework.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You can watch live session replace to discover where users are breezing through your flow and where they struggle.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable product-research guidance: use session replays to identify friction points and smooth paths in real user flows.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You can view instant heat maps to see what parts of your page users are engaging with and what content they're ignoring.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical method for diagnosing attention and engagement—heatmaps reveal what users notice versus skip.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: you can identify product opportunities, conversion wins, and find big gaps between how you imagine people using your product and how they actually use it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable product insight: instrumenting real behavior helps uncover opportunity by exposing mismatches between assumptions and reality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you listen to this podcast, you know how often we talk about the importance of knowing your users and by seeing how users truly experience your product, you can identify product opportunities, conversion wins, and find big gaps between how you imagine people using your product and how they actually use it.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Highlights a practical user-research mindset: observe real behavior to uncover opportunities and mismatches between assumptions and reality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can also pinpoint what's bothering your users with really cool frustration metrics like rage clicks, and dead clicks and much more.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Gives concrete, actionable metrics practitioners can use to diagnose UX friction beyond traditional analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You'll never run into traffic limits or be forced to upgrade to a paid version.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: A specific product claim that can influence tool selection and experimentation decisions for teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective and I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Provides a concrete acceptance-rate data point signaling selectivity and potential candidate quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can be anonymous and you can even hide yourself from specific companies.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: A counterintuitive job-search feature that reduces risk for candidates while exploring opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Scale of Duarte’s presentation work
quotes.text: So, I had a president who took us a whack at that number in, it was 2014, and he said at that time it was 225,000, and that was almost 10 years ago, so I can't even tell you, I mean we stopped tracking, but it's a lot.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Gives a concrete scale data point (225k in 2014) and highlights how quickly counts become outdated if you stop tracking.

quotes.topic_title: Scale of Duarte’s presentation work
quotes.text: I mean, in 35 years we have thousands of projects we open and each sometimes has two to a hundred presentations in it, so it'd be hard to tell.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Offers a practical way to think about volume: projects as containers that can generate many presentations each.

quotes.topic_title: Scale of Duarte’s presentation work
quotes.text: He said 250,000, but that was 10 years ago and I didn't do the math.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Reinforces the magnitude with a second specific estimate while acknowledging uncertainty in long-running metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Scale of Duarte’s presentation work
quotes.text: It's like every little startup and then they grew to massive brands like Cisco and you could actually look at the rise and fall of all these companies.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Frames presentation work as a unique longitudinal lens on company trajectories—an unexpected way to value archives.

quotes.topic_title: Scale of Duarte’s presentation work
quotes.text: And then I actually have all the decks. I still have a lot of these archives, so I could actually verify that number exactly.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Highlights the operational insight that keeping deck archives enables later verification and analysis at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Most memorable project: An Inconvenient Truth
quotes.text: it came out before TED Talks were even out on the web, and so people had never seen someone tell a data story and stand in front of data and the scale in 90 foot screen,
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Highlights how novelty in format and scale can make data storytelling feel unprecedented and memorable.

quotes.topic_title: Most memorable project: An Inconvenient Truth
quotes.text: And he would literally pause and touch his chin and really think, and really consider that we might actually be experts.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A practical model for great collaboration: leaders create better outcomes by genuinely deferring to domain experts.

quotes.topic_title: Most memorable project: An Inconvenient Truth
quotes.text: So, he would go city to city to city, because he was traveling for five years seeding, like planting seeds for a groundswell,
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Offers a repeatable go-to-market approach for ideas: sustained repetition and “seeding” builds momentum before a breakout moment.

quotes.topic_title: Most memorable project: An Inconvenient Truth
quotes.text: I said, "Wow, that's going to be a lot of work we'd have to do for free, and who's going to go see a movie about a slideshow anyway?" That's literally what I said.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that even experts can underestimate audience demand—so test assumptions about what will resonate.

quotes.topic_title: Most memorable project: An Inconvenient Truth
quotes.text: I mean, at the end, when he traveled around for those five years at the end, he always had a slide with our name on it and would thank us if you're in the audience.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Shows a concrete practice for building long-term partnerships: public credit and gratitude reinforce trust and commitment.

quotes.topic_title: Seeding impact and scaling a movement
quotes.text: It also makes me think about a pattern that I often see of it wasn't just one presentation that changed everything.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the repeatable pattern that impact usually comes from sustained effort rather than a single “big moment.”

quotes.topic_title: Seeding impact and scaling a movement
quotes.text: It was, you said five years of prep ahead of that, and you always see these wow overnight success stories and you always find, okay, it wasn't actually that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete reminder to plan for long lead times and iterative refinement behind any “breakthrough” talk or movement.

quotes.topic_title: Seeding impact and scaling a movement
quotes.text: we built a whole training program where he could fly people out to his place in Tennessee and start to train people.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Shows a practical scaling mechanism: turning a successful talk into a structured training program.

quotes.topic_title: Seeding impact and scaling a movement
quotes.text: So, it almost became a train the trainer and he could sanction you as a ambassador for it.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Introduces a scalable “train-the-trainer” model with certification/authorization to multiply advocates while maintaining quality.

quotes.topic_title: Landing Apple and early desktop publishing era
quotes.text: So, what happened was I made some phone calls. I called NASA and I called Tandem, which is now HP, and I called Apple and we won contracts at all three brands at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete example of using direct outbound (cold calling) to land major enterprise clients immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Landing Apple and early desktop publishing era
quotes.text: And we slipped in. When you talk about a product lifecycle, very early, everything was still bit mappy, was not attractive.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Highlights a timing strategy: entering a market at the very early product lifecycle stage when others dismiss it.

quotes.topic_title: Landing Apple and early desktop publishing era
quotes.text: And there's about an 18 month window in the life cycle of the Macintosh where graphic designers refused to use it, refused.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A specific data point about an adoption gap that created an opportunity for early movers.

quotes.topic_title: Landing Apple and early desktop publishing era
quotes.text: And that's right when we entered right then went and checked out books at the library on type setting, we tried to figure out what we could do, what could we do with this tool, and then the rest was kind of history.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Shows an actionable playbook: enter early, then rapidly skill up to become the expert in an emerging tool.

quotes.topic_title: Landing Apple and early desktop publishing era
quotes.text: Cold calling. Cold calling, yeah, it was.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable confirmation that old-school outbound outreach was the mechanism behind landing marquee clients.

quotes.topic_title: What Apple taught about visual presentation craft
quotes.text: I don't know how you're going to do it, but I want you to take the whole slide.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete directive that pushes practitioners toward full-bleed, single-idea slides instead of text-heavy teleprompters.

quotes.topic_title: What Apple taught about visual presentation craft
quotes.text: I want you to just make the whole slide, it's just covered with the word big in hot pink. And I want the background black, because when this slide pops up in all pink big, I want it to actually light the faces of the people in the audience.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A vivid example of designing for audience impact and focus using extreme simplicity, contrast, and intentional stagecraft.

quotes.topic_title: What Apple taught about visual presentation craft
quotes.text: Putting the tool in the hands of the masses kind of destroyed the medium itself.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that democratized slide tools often lead to worse communication unless craft is intentionally restored.

quotes.topic_title: What Apple taught about visual presentation craft
quotes.text: But we take their brand guidelines and really push it into the spoken word medium where when they stand up on a stage, it's cinematic. The visuals can become an experience in itself.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A practical methodology: translate brand guidelines into stage-ready, cinematic visuals rather than generic templates.

quotes.topic_title: What Apple taught about visual presentation craft
quotes.text: The audience just likes it better when it's really clear what you're supposed to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A simple, actionable principle for slide design: clarity of focal point is a primary driver of audience preference.

quotes.topic_title: Three rules to start any deck
quotes.text: Your audience is the hero.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A simple framing rule that shifts the deck from presenter-centric to audience-centric, guiding what to include and how to position it.

quotes.topic_title: Three rules to start any deck
quotes.text: I would say it's infuse your talk with story.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A tactical reminder to apply story structure rather than defaulting to a linear “beginning, middle, end” information dump.

quotes.topic_title: Three rules to start any deck
quotes.text: And I would say it is asking yourself, can they see what I'm saying?
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A practical test for clarity and visual communication—ensuring the audience can grasp the message, not just hear it.

quotes.topic_title: Empathy and the audience-as-hero mindset
quotes.text: every single book and every single model that I ever make has empathy at the core because you have to have to think about who am I speaking with, especially in communication, who am I speaking with?
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Makes empathy a practical design constraint: start by explicitly identifying and designing for the audience you’re speaking with.

quotes.topic_title: Empathy and the audience-as-hero mindset
quotes.text: who really holds the power in the room of a presentation is the audience, the audience gets to make a choice if they accept or reject your idea. So, the balance of power is with them and not you.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Counterintuitive power dynamic that reframes persuasion as audience choice rather than presenter control.

quotes.topic_title: Empathy and the audience-as-hero mindset
quotes.text: So, it really is the role of the presenter to be the mentor.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A clear role framework: presenters should act as mentors guiding the audience (the hero) rather than positioning themselves as the hero.

quotes.topic_title: Empathy and the audience-as-hero mindset
quotes.text: So, when you're speaking to an audience, they're going to have an internal conflict that you have to give them something to soothe. And then you're asking them to therefore go and do this thing, take this action, do this call to action.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Actionable structure for talks: address internal resistance first, then make the external ask/call-to-action.

quotes.topic_title: Empathy and the audience-as-hero mindset
quotes.text: And so you have to change your mindset when you're starting to build your deck to think about who am I talking to? How am I going to help them get unstuck?
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Practical deck-building checklist that operationalizes empathy into two guiding questions.

quotes.topic_title: How Duarte pressure-tests internal presentations
quotes.text: So, in my own company, before I do a presentation that's going to require goals or them reaching goals or we do an annual vision talk, we do a listening tour first.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable pre-work practice for pressure-testing internal presentations before asking people to change behavior or hit goals.

quotes.topic_title: How Duarte pressure-tests internal presentations
quotes.text: And we feed that information up and then we compare it to what we're going to ask them to do. And we do some gap analysis.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A simple methodology: collect audience input, compare it to the ask, and explicitly identify gaps to address in the message.

quotes.topic_title: How Duarte pressure-tests internal presentations
quotes.text: And then what we do is I create a real rough cut or the exec team creates a real rough cut and then we invite the next level of leaders in and we do a fake, I mean the slides are ugly, we don't spend time on the slides.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: An actionable process for iterating on message quality early—test with leaders using an intentionally rough draft rather than polishing slides first.

quotes.topic_title: How Duarte pressure-tests internal presentations
quotes.text: This is about the message and maybe a model or two or three that we're going to go through to feel like it may amplify or make the message more concrete.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: focus iteration on message clarity and a small number of models that make the message concrete, not slide aesthetics.

quotes.topic_title: How Duarte pressure-tests internal presentations
quotes.text: So, we go through that knowing that's the hardest presentation I deliver all year.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that internal presentations can be harder than external talks, reinforcing the need for more rigorous internal pressure-testing.

quotes.topic_title: Story structure: what is vs what could be
quotes.text: if you're telling me a story and I'm listening, our brains are firing in the exact same order, in the exact same place. So, it has power to align our brains.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A science-backed rationale for using story: it literally synchronizes speaker and audience cognition.

quotes.topic_title: Story structure: what is vs what could be
quotes.text: story kind of builds tension and releases it.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A practical design principle for talks: deliberately alternate tension and resolution to keep attention and drive emotion.

quotes.topic_title: Story structure: what is vs what could be
quotes.text: So, story creates longing. It helps people long for something they'd never wanted before because if the future is told in the shape of a story and they see this alternate future
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A memorable explanation of how narrative can create desire for change by making an alternate future feel real.

quotes.topic_title: Story structure: what is vs what could be
quotes.text: you could picture a line at the bottom of your screen and that line going left to is what is. And you need to set up every talk by stating what is. And then it moves straight up and you move to what could be come back down to the bottom line again say what is, back up, what could be, what is, what could be, what is, what could be? And then at the last what could be you state the last horizontal line is what we call the new bliss.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable story-structure template (“what is / what could be / new bliss”) for shaping persuasive presentations.

quotes.topic_title: Story structure: what is vs what could be
quotes.text: So, this motion of traversing between what is, what could be, what's is, what could be, what is, what could be, that sense of longing for the future, it makes people leave their current state or the status quo or our current reality and makes them long for this future state by using contrast.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: An actionable mechanism: use contrast repeatedly to pull audiences away from the status quo toward a desired future.

quotes.topic_title: Using contrast in any moment of influence
quotes.text: But I'll tell you a dirty little secret. I can get my husband to do chores for me on the weekends with a real quick, what is, what could be new bliss, kind of just that first bit, what is, what could be new bliss.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Shows the “what is / what could be / new bliss” contrast model can be used in everyday influence, not just formal presentations.

quotes.topic_title: Using contrast in any moment of influence
quotes.text: So, the ability to just have that contrast as a framework in your brain during a meeting, on a phone call, any moment of influence, getting the husband to do some chores for me, literally it works. It works in any format.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that the contrast framework is portable across formats (meetings, calls, casual asks).

quotes.topic_title: Using contrast in any moment of influence
quotes.text: And we realized that when we tangle it's usually only about process.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterintuitive diagnostic: many conflicts are process mismatches, which you can address by clarifying “what is” before proposing “what could be.”

quotes.topic_title: Using contrast in any moment of influence
quotes.text: It has a beginning, middle, and an end. So, the first, what is is the beginning. The middle is the messy middle. That's where you're trying to contrast and show them that it's messy. It might be hard, it's worth it. And then the new bliss, you end with what in western cultures, where's like a happy ending.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Maps the story arc to a simple structure practitioners can apply immediately when crafting a narrative or pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Using contrast in any moment of influence
quotes.text: Empathetically at my company, everyone knows each other's love language. They know that this person feels more appreciated when they get a written note. This person feels more appreciated when they get a gift and everyone knows that.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Concrete example of operationalizing empathy by tailoring communication to what makes each person feel valued.

quotes.topic_title: Make audiences see what you’re saying
quotes.text: Oh, it was ask yourself if they can see what you're saying. Can they see what I'm saying would be written on the note?
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic question you can apply to any talk to pressure-test whether your message is concretely visualizable.

quotes.topic_title: Make audiences see what you’re saying
quotes.text: I would contend that you can use something in your talk that gives people something they'll always remember. We call that a star moment.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable technique—designing a “star moment”—to make key points stick via a memorable visual, story, or data beat.

quotes.topic_title: Make audiences see what you’re saying
quotes.text: If you're in a interesting conversation and you want someone to see what you're saying, that's where you pull out the napkin and you draw it.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Practical advice for creating alignment without slides by externalizing your mental model in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Make audiences see what you’re saying
quotes.text: And then the room will stand up and we'll start all co-creating a graphic so that everyone sees the exact same thing, the exact same steps, the exact same insights in the order. So, nobody leaves with a question in their mind.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete facilitation method—co-creating a shared diagram—to eliminate ambiguity and ensure shared understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Make audiences see what you’re saying
quotes.text: And the other thing we try to get our customers to do is, if Dr. King had slides that day of the I Have a Dream speech, it just wouldn't been as beautiful. His words painted the pictures in our mind's eye.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that removing slides can increase impact by forcing the audience to visualize through language.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical slide advice: one point per slide
quotes.text: Yeah, the concept that each slide should make one point.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage rule for slide construction that reduces cognitive load and clarifies what each slide is doing.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical slide advice: one point per slide
quotes.text: So, your whole presentation should be grounded in what we call the audience journey, which is the big idea where you're trying to move them from where you're trying to move them to.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Introduces a framing model (“audience journey”) for organizing the entire talk around a movement from current state to desired state.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical slide advice: one point per slide
quotes.text: If you're making what we call a slide doc, which I think your listenership would be interested in, presentations go from big staged event to in a meeting where you're trying to persuade your peers too.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Defines a distinct artifact type (“slide doc”) and when to use it versus a stage deck.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical slide advice: one point per slide
quotes.text: And so I think the one idea per slide is important. And then this guiding principle, don't make a single slide unless it supports the one big idea of your whole talk.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Adds a second filter beyond “one point per slide”: every slide must directly support the talk’s central idea.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical slide advice: one point per slide
quotes.text: And sometimes you're speaking to an audience that wants high density slides, because that's how they communicate in their culture. And if you showed up with cinematic stage ready slides, they'd laugh you out of the room.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “better” slides depend on audience culture—cinematic minimalism can backfire in high-density environments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of how robust experimentation tooling enables deeper segmentation and faster learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more delivering results quickly, avoiding annoying prolonged analytics cycles and helping you easily get to the root cause of any issue you discover.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable value proposition for experimentation teams: shorten analytics cycles and improve root-cause analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Sometimes it's effective.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Counterpoint to one-size-fits-all presentation rules: effectiveness depends on audience and situation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And then also how the construct of it is and when you state the conclusion first, that's a great thing to do with execs. It's a great thing to do when you are fundraising.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Practical guidance on when to lead with the conclusion—especially for executive audiences and fundraising contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Because I would say you start with the new bliss.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Memorable framing for pitching: open by painting the improved future state before unpacking details.

quotes.topic_title: Minto Pyramid and leading with conclusions
quotes.text: And then also how the construct of it is and when you state the conclusion first, that's a great thing to do with execs. It's a great thing to do when you are fundraising.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: Clear guidance on when a conclusion-first (Minto) structure is most effective—executive and fundraising audiences.

quotes.topic_title: Minto Pyramid and leading with conclusions
quotes.text: There's a certain type of an audience that works for, and there's other audiences where they really need to be taught to long for this future state and you need longer to unpack it.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A counterpoint to “always lead with the conclusion”: some audiences need a slower build that creates desire for the future state.

quotes.topic_title: Minto Pyramid and leading with conclusions
quotes.text: Because I would say you start with the new bliss.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A memorable alternative framing of “conclusion-first”: open with the improved future state rather than a traditional results summary.

quotes.topic_title: Minto Pyramid and leading with conclusions
quotes.text: So, if you're trying to raise funds, you would say, I am going to share with you something today and you share how your solution increases human flourishing.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A practical fundraising opener that anchors the pitch in human benefit, not just product or metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Minto Pyramid and leading with conclusions
quotes.text: It needs to be tied to the humanness and the big problem you're going to solve and how humankind will benefit.
quotes.speaker: Nancy Duarte
quotes.context: A concrete checklist for shaping a conclusion-first message around human stakes and societal upside.
